Author: Alright#0419
Content: likelihood of being able to pull that off is *slim*

Author: sgp#7572
Content: before I go (I dispute the above), do you have a formal analysis for your dPoW setup? anything beyond the whitepaper and recent blog post I should be referring to?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: getting a better mining ROI by getting notaries to collude

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: checkpoints work to prevent reorgs past that checkpoint

Author: Alright#0419
Content: you would need significantly more than 13 notaries to collude because notaries can't pick and choose who they will notarize with

Author: peritonlogon#7708
Content: @sgp there seems to be a lot of talking past each  other  here.  Why not just perform your attack and prove you're right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW is not doing anything mathematical, it is purely about the implementation

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: @peritonlogon i wanted to suggest the same

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the formal analysis is that if a block is not reorged, no tx in that block can be double spent

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: try if you can double spend notarized tx and show us

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: he can also try that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notaries can suppress notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but dpowconfs allows all nodes to detect lack of notarizations

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: how many nodes he can align by the attackers side?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for attack analysis we assume 100% notary collusion

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we show even in that case, there is no meaningful attack

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I believe I have done that but @sgp feels there is still some chart that will show me notaries can double spend

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: what purpose we have to collude?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, it is an interesting angle and we did find that colluding notaries can gain a bit of mining ROI to 51% mine a notarized chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it will be detected, hard to miss reorgs with every notarization

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: the way i see it is, my stay with mainnet and keep my nodes well maintained to perform better securing the network and mine my allotment of easy diff KMD. if i make it top 30 nodes, i get chance of be there another year. Moar KMD

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @jl777c I still find that attack vector entirely implausible

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it assumes that there aren't honest notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but that is what attack analysis is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assume the worst and if the worst is a bit of mining ROI gained by orphaning competing chains, with the expenditure of 51% hashrate and it is discoverable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if that is the worst, then you evaluate that it is not any practical issue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but if a suicidal attack could do massive double spends, that is one thing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in this case it is an uneconomic attack

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: devaluing one currency might make another one more valuable I guess

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you make the worst case assumptions, find the worst attack and do a risk assessment

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: Then try to protect the currency form that risk right

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Always interested in testing attack vectors, if anyone does come up with a viable one, please let me know

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: Yeah, but I guess you need to be careful about how you let the community know. Otherwise people will panic and that can affect coin prices.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @jl777c this has me wondering what would happen if we had two segregated subsets of the notary network both notarizing separate forks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Alright it would devolved to longest chain

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: Notary is like an added layer of security

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but with the number of notaries, when there have been chain splits, the notaries stop notarizing as they cant reach consensus

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: because you see Komodo block chains work on delayed proof of work. All computers must approve of the mathematical result before a transaction is executed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: realistically such a chain split will require corrective actions, ie. resync on nodes that end up on the shorter chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: new nodes will automatically go to the longer chain, we have seen this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if you end up on the shorter notarized chain, then you need to resync

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but such things only happen very rarely and there is a way to resolve it, just messy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: keep in mind all chain splits are a messy business

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: Komodo also creates a back up of itself to a different block chain, this is notarization.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what conditions?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is very unlikely, as notaries wont reach consensus if there is a chain split

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: can this be prevented by making another notarized layer, like a back up of the notarized chain. Therefore adding another layer of secuirty?

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: ah, i see.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is very unlikely, as notaries wont reach consensus if there is a chain split

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it does happen, we certainly notice it and notary on the wrong chain, resync

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: So, what are the main factors causing the notaries to reach consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: agreement about (height, blockhash)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if they have the same hash, they reach consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if by rare condition two chains are both notarized, the notaries wipe out the wrong chain and eventually all nodes sync to the right chain. eventual consensus after a messy mess

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: iguana is pretty clever

Author: GlorymanRTS#0512
Content: And this is mainly secured by 51% of the hashrate.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: plz read the discussion above, i wont repeat it

Author: sφldat#8733
Content: Thank you for this very interesting discussion, should we expect an attack on Komodo to definitively prove the solidity of dPoW?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it has been tried, but even skeptics now seem to admit that rewriting notarized blocks is futile, so now they are saying the big giant problem is that if all the notaries collude they can get a slightly higher mining ROI for notarized chains if they get more than 51% the hashrate for that chain. Of course, they will be found out quickly, and if it wasnt notarized they could just do double spends, but this is the worst attack so far discovered with all the notaries colluding to do evil

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course, our notaries are good people and they wont be doing any such colluding, it was just a thought experiment to find out what is the worst case

Author: sφldat#8733
Content: In this case it is obvious that the worst situations can be found in everything and therefore no technology is ever really perfect.  But there are solutions that sometimes remain the best in a specific field and this is the case of dPoW for blockchain security.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, dPoW isnt perfect (nothing is), but it sure is better than no dPoW

Author: Alright#0419
Content:
`now they are saying the big giant problem is that if all the notaries collude they can get a slightly higher mining ROI for notarized chains if they get more than 51% the hashrate for that chain.`

Key word there is *all*

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a fantasy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and even if it happens the only financial gain is some minimal increase due to having to mine a longer chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for all that work it would be easier to just 51% attack and double spend a non-notarized chain

Author: sgp#7572
Content: Hey @jl777c, thanks for talking with me yesterday. I'm back with two diagrams and one simple question: which chain would nodes consider to be valid?

Author: sgp#7572
Content: Diagram 1: https://i.imgur.com/ySkCOOr.png

Author: sgp#7572
Content: Diagram 2: https://i.imgur.com/oRHME4s.png

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: chainB wont be accepted by nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even evil notaries wont be able to convince them to accept it as the notarization already happened after the third block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anything at or prior to the notarization will be rejected, by nodes that have validated a notarization

Author: sgp#7572
Content: Let's take diagram 1 and say a specific node saw chain B first. Would it reject chain A?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: first you need to realize the second slide scenario wont happen, as both A and B cant be notarized

Author: sgp#7572
Content: I'm talking about diagram 1 right now

Author: sgp#7572
Content: chain B doesn't have a notarization in diagram 1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, in that case a node sees chain B, but it wont be notarized

Author: sgp#7572
Content: right, so the node would accept chain B as correct, and ignore chain A, correct?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: chain B node will be operating as normal rules

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when chain A becomes longer than chain B, the normal rules apply and chain B node will reorg to the longer chain A.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at that point it sees the chain A notarization and wont switch back to B

Author: sgp#7572
Content: all right, I understand where you are coming from there

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so in a chain split, nodes on the non-notarized chain can switch to the notarized one, but not the other way around. this reduces the time it takes for the "eventual consensus"

Author: sgp#7572
Content: understood

Author: sgp#7572
Content: now on to diagram 2

Author: sgp#7572
Content: can you explain why a notarization of the second chain isn't possible?
